author: Jcc2224
title: Cool Figure!
review:
I was able to get a TRU employee to sell me one of these figures. The sad thing is it's the cheaper figure from the Magnet set. I didn't open it(because I have an opened magnet) but the figure has cool chrome silver elements. You can use the right leg on your C-3PO to give it that silver leg.

You might be able to go to TRU and buy one instead of Buying 10.99 worth of LEGO Star Wars. Get it today, and start your LEGO investment! :)

author: eddy847
title: A Great Minifig
review:
I got this minifig at my local TRU with the republic swamp speeder, and was pleasantly suprised that they still had some in stock (it was the last day of the offer). since this is only one minifig, I don't think it needs a long introduction. sooo, on to the pros and cons.

pros:

  • actually really reflective
  • goes well with chrome vader

 cons:

  • I now understand what they mean by "cheap chinese plastic".
  • if you take it apart, it gives the impression that they took a regular white stormie, and dipped it in silver paint.

author: Pepper
title: Shiny!
review:
I got this set the day before the end of the promotion by buying another Clone Walker Battle Pack. He is really cool. I used him to make a Stormtrooper commander for Darth Vader (not chrome).
 

Pros
shiny
silver
stormtrooper
blaster
 

Cons
not fully silver
expensive if you would get it by itself
Overall, this is a really cool promo. He is a really good addition to any Imperial army. I would maybe buy him off of ebay, but probably not.

author: legomaster59
title: pretty pretty shiny shiny!
review: I got this at toys r us a while ago but just wrote the review. I got it from buying the snowtrooper battlepack. The set has no building experience despite my rating on the side. Great playability and a great value for money. Overall I give this a 4/5.

author: Jarod98
title: 2853590-1: Chrome Stormtrooper
review: This is simply amazing! I got this at my local Toys "R" Us by buying the '8093-1: Plo Koon's Jedi Starfighter' set. Since there's only 5 pieces, no instruction, and it's completely built when you get it I didn't rate the 'Building experience' category. I gave the 'Parts' category five stars because 3/5 pieces are chrome. I didn't rate the 'Playability' category since there's only a Stormtrooper in this. For value of money, I gave it five stars because it was free. It would be nice if the blaster was chrome to go with the Chrome Stormtrooper, and this goes really well with the Chrome Darth Vader (duh). So overall, not much, except awesomeness!

author: pod120
title: The Only TRU Product That Wasn't Overpriced
review:
Introduction

 

I got this set for free at TRU for spend over one hundred dollars AUD on LEGO. You may have had to of spend more or less than that, but it was an amount that was probably somewhere between one hundred and one hundred and fifty dollars AUD. This review is going to be very personal, as opinions about this LEGO set, or better named as LEGO product will differ greatly between different people. There will be people who like this novelty very much," It's a great little minifig that will probably hold a lot of value and as an individual figure, cannot be made any better". There will also be people who think that it is terrible,"It's just a boring old minifig, everyone has got a Stormtrooper". I can't say I have a lot of experience with the minifig, as I am yet to open the packet.

 

The Minifigure

 

The minifigure is technically the only thing included other than the blaster and the packaging. There isn't even an instruction leaflet. The minifig was already mostly constructed in the packet when I got it. I am unsure if the pieces are detachable or if the head, torso and legs are permanently stuck together. Only his helmet and blaster were loose. I have divided the explainantion of the minifig into four parts.

 

-The head is the same part as most minifig heads. It is a standard black and doesn't appear to be special or unique in any way. As I have not opened the packet, I do not know if the head can be removed from the torso. Being a single colour may not appear as a positive for some people. Some people may have wanted for the head to have detail, but has there ever been a Stormtrooper minifig without a black head?

-The torso is rather detailed and is a very shiny chrome silver. The silver is infact so shiny that sometimes the pieces almost look transparent. Other than printings, the hands are the only part of the torso that is not silver. The torso has printing on both sides. Most of the printing is surrounded by a shade of white, which gives more detail to the minifig. All of the printings on the torso are either a black, white or grey colour. From what I can see, it appears that the arms are moveable.

-The legs are the same, shiny chrome silver as the torso. The legs do not have any printing at all. I wonder if LEGO's method of colouring the minifig, or even just its legs was by use of spraying paint. I thought this after seeing the inside of the legs. One leg was painted silver on the inside and the other was left white on the inside. It is questionable whether this was or wasn't intentional and whether or not this is a positive. The legs seem to move very easily from what I can do with the packet still sealed. I am unsure if they can be detached from the torso.

-The helmet is probably the most interesting piece of the set. It is the same chrome silver as the torso and legs. When I got the packet, the helmet was already loose, but may have initially been connected to the minifig's head. I do know that Stormtrooper helmets commonly pop off of minifigs' heads which they have been placed on. The shape is good and I believe it is the same piece as the original Stormtrooper helmet. The printings are very detailed and are made up of black, grey and and dark blue colours.

 

The Accessory

 

The only other LEGO piece included is the blaster. It is a standard blaster seen in the Star Wars line and I believe the piece was first seen in 2007, along with a similar piece which was slightly longer. The piece has a complex mould and will go for a long time before it will seem outdated. The blaster has three points at which it can be clasped in the minifig's hand.

 

The Packaging

 

I wouldn't normally mention anything about the packaging or instructions in a review, but because this LEGO product is so small, I will give a brief explaination of the packaging. The big "Star Wars" is in red and has the same design as mid 2009 and early 2010 The Clone Wars sets with the three Clone Troopers design. The information bar states that the set is intended for peoples aged 6+, the official name is "Stormtrooper" and that the set, or product contains 5 pieces. The LEGO Star Wars website address is also displayed. The back pretty much only has common packaging details such as choking hazard, recycling symbol and barcode.

 

Conclusion

 

So in the end it is up to you whether this set is a positive or negative. It would be impossible for everyone to agree on where the set, or product lies between a rating of one and five. I think that as a promotional bonus, the set is everything it needs to be. It is detailed, it includes an accessory, it is an iconic licensed character and it is a colour that is rarely seen in LEGO. When it comes to building and playing, it is difficult to judge this product, but should it be judged on these things? It's technically not even a LEGO "set". Is it a good LEGO product? Has anyone ever written so many words for only five pieces? All of these questions' answers ultimately remain with you.

author: Phantom
title: Looks better in the packet!
review:
There isnt too much too say about this minifigure, its a stormtrooper but chrome!
When you first see this figure, you notice its very shiny and has a very reflective surface but there is however a con.
Certain parts of the trooper in the 'chroming' process were skipped out, mainly the back of the arms which gives this 'special' guy a cheap feeling.
The parts are very good, offering you a range of minifig bits in chrome so you can take this guy apart and use his parts to make a custom.
I got 2 of these free from TRU with the purchase of Battle of Endor and Count Dooku's solar sailer.
Generally the minifigure is best kept in the packet as it looks much better but i probably may have opened one of them up if i didnt have an already opened one from the magnet set.
The printing also seems to be much cheaper as my 'rough' one has lost nearly all his torso printing just from staying in my minifigure box! The chrome is however pretty hard wearing and not easy to scratch or maybe you cant print as good on chrome?
Overall this guy is pretty cool to have but dont go too crazy as its just a shiny stormtrooper!

author: Lobot7
title: Great Deal....
review:
I just got one and there was a sale so I bought one for $2.99 and got one for free so I bought three and got three free. Although I got a great deal I do not I repeat do not like the newer stormtrooper and would rather have the older helmet in chrome.

Although 4 out of 5, not bad...

author: plantman
title: It was free! But why would a  stormtrooper be chrome plated??
review: First off, it was free from Toys r' us for spending more than $30 on Lego.  Nothing to complain about (I got six of them that day - for nothing!).  I love having extra stormtroopers - you can never have too many.  But why did it have to be chrome?  Chrome makes no sense to me - I would have preferred white.  I understand the "collectible" aspect, but I hate the turn that Lego is taking with the whole rare, collectible minifigure market.  Still, it's a stormtrooper with a blaster, which is always cool - in any color.

author: tfcrafter
title: Not bad
review:
I got this minifig as part of a promotion by TRU Canada in 2011, where you spend over $40 on Lego Star Wars stuff and you would get this VERY SHINY minifig.

Box/Instructions

Pretty simple, your standard polybag with a blown-up picture of the chrometrooper. Very shiny.

Parts

Nothing special, comes with a blaster, your standard minifig mold.

Minifigures

Well, this is where it gets special. The chrome minifigure is stunning from a distance (I almost blinded myself because the sun was reflecting off the paint). However, when you go up close and move the limbs, you will see white plastic (the original stormtrooper colour). This may take away from the whole "chrominess" of the minifigure, but I assure you, it is quite worth it (better than that useless TC-14 who got 2 minutes of screen time). Very shiny though.

The build

Um...fun?? I mean, it's like your standard minifigure build. Except more shiny. Very shiny.

Results

Is it worth it? Sure. You can find it for less than $30 on Ebay. Is it essential to your collection? Well, unless you're a minifigure completist, it isn't that important for your collection. I would recommend saving your money and buying something else instead.
